text: THE CAMERA LOOKS DOWN ON three levels of escalators  transporting a smattering of Southwestern shoppers -- som in cowboy hats.
A SERIES OF ANGLES of shoppers being conveyed up and down
A beautiful vista -- cacti and sage dot the landscape as rises to mountains in the distance.
THE CAMERA PANS revealing an island of modern culture --  malls and more malls, parking lots, and fast food franchi
A brown Pinto pulls out of a parking lot and into rush ho traffic.

BETH WALKER is driving. She looks younger, but she's twen eight. She has a strong face and flashing intelligent eye She's wearing a WAITRESS UNIFORM from Friendly's. She's d in thought. Beth pulls up to stoplight and stops. SOUND: A gentle toot of car horn. Beth looks up, startled.
SID, a pleasant looking twenty-four year old, is in a pic up truck next to her. He smiles and points up toward the  traffic light.
She looks up toward the traffic light.
They're red except for one with a lit green arrow.
She pantomimes that she's in the wrong lane and wants to straight. Sid pantomimes that he'll let her cut in front of him. SOUND: Horns honk impatiently.
Beth pulls away in front of the pick-up truck. The HONKIN continues. Sid looks back at the honking car, cheerfully  waves to it.
A tiny well-kept Spanish style home in lower middle class residential section.

It's neat and smartly furnished -- discount Swedish moder framed deco posters, some nice plants. The only problem i it seems a little more like a well-designed waiting room  than a home. There's an empty ice bucket, several empty liquor bottles and a swinging metal ball thingabobby on a chrome and gla coffee table in front of leather sofa. CAROL AND NICK are curled up together on the sofa, drinks hand. They're both in their late twenties. Carol's dressed in t casually stylish clothes worn by women who work in shoppi mall boutiques. Nick's clothes are frumpled, a knit tie loose around his  neck. They've achieved a state of contemplative drunkenne Carol sips her drink. Nick sips his drink. Carol sips her drink. Nick brings his glass to his lips, hesitates...
(flatly) We're moving.
What?
(enunciating) We're going to move.
(after a beat) When?
Two days.
In two days?!
Yeah.
Carol shakes her head in weary disbelief.
(covering her hurt) Thanks for the news...
She knocks back her drink. Nick broods.
I haven't known for long. I just  decided. (ruminating) What do I need that makes me make  these decisions?
Carol stares at him. He knocks back his drink.
You got me.
She pours herself another drink.
What does Beth say?
Beth?...
She stops at an intersection.
Whatever makes me happy. That's what  she says...
Headlights flash from behind her. She turns and looks.
Sid's smiling from his truck right behind her. He flashes his lights again.
Beth looks up in the rearview mirror, amused.
Sid turns off, disappearing into the night.
Surprised to find herself vaguely disappointed, she drive on.
It's small, prefab, and tidy. It has a counter with shutt that open onto the living room. Nick is kneeling, going  through bottles in a cabinet.
(w/ drunken desperation) I know this place.
Nick stands, with an almost empty bottle of Johnny Walker Red.
I know what happens here.
He pours himself a drink. Carol shuts the cabinet.
I know what's going to happen.

Nick opens a cabinet under the sink and tosses the empty  bottle in the trash. He begins to pace. Carol shuts the  cabinet and follows him with her gaze. As Nick speaks, he gestures grandly with his drink, liquo splashing unnoticed over the sides.
(bursting with  frustration) The same job, same scenery, same  people... I've been in this town for  years... Years!!
(flatly) Three years.
(in despair) Oh, Carol...
I know...
He stops and slugs back his drink.
Forever -- it seems forever.
Beth pulls up to a stoplight, her face blank with thought She's suddenly lit by the flash of headlights going on an off. She looks up and smiles.
Sid's pick-up truck is facing her across the intersection It slowly pulls up beside her and stops. He smiles and gives a little wave of his hand. Without knowing why, she smiles and waves back.
(sweetly but firmly) Good-bye.
She drives away. Sid stares after her.
Carol lifts the end metal ball on the thingabobby and rel it, starting the chain reaction. She stares at it clackin back and forth as she speaks.
How long a drive is it?
Nick paces.
Fourteen hours.
That's not bad.
In a car? It's a fuckin' nightmare.
Carol stops the metal ball. She releases two balls, start a new chain reaction.
(griping) And there's no radio in Utah. It's  all religious programs.
Get saved.
Nick slumps on the sofa beside her.
(flatly) No thanks.
Hey. Think about this. You take a  detour and go through Vegas -- you  and Beth stop, see a show, have a  nice romantic dinner -- play the  slots, get the free drinks...
(interrupting) Too much money. The show. The meal.  The slots. Then the hotel -- that's  another hundred down the toilet.
As Carol speaks she pokes at Nick. He fends off her blows By the end of her speech she is on top of him mock-strang him.

(jabbing Nick) No, you skip the hotel. It's night,  the highway's empty -- you can make  good time. You start speeding. You  get stopped in Utah by the cops --  you flunk the breathalizer, they  haul you in. The judge is Mormon --  you get fifteen years, you go to  prison, but at least your life has  taken a direction!
Nick and Carol collapse into laughter. The front door ope
(calling in) I'm here!
Beth steps in. Carol quickly lets go of Nick's neck and g off him.
Embarrassed, they both smile self-consciously. There's an awkward instant followed by too much cheerfuln
(chipper) Hi!
Hi, honey.
Hi.
stands in the doorway, awkwardly conscious of having  interrupted something.
(w/ forced cheer) Hi.
Nick and Beth are standing in the lawn, lit by the glow o the porch lamp. Both sides of the street are lined with nearly identical  tiny faux Spanish houses.
G'night.
Carol waves.
G'night.
(calling out) Pizza Hut, tomorrow?
Okay. (to Beth) I've got the short shift -- you want  me to come over, help pack?
Great... I'm really sorry we didn't  tell you sooner. He just decided.
smiles to herself, a trace of sadness in her eyes.
I understand.
She shuts the door.
She starts to walk across the lawn. She stops and stares Nick, who's staring out into the night, oblivious to her.
I'm tired. I'm going to bed.
He turns and looks at her.
What's your problem?
I haven't got a problem.
Okay.
He walks up to her and past her -- when she doesn't fall  into step, he stops.
You agreed to try Billings.
I know. (in Nick's words) Billings, Montana. City of the future.
Yeah and I read that a while ago --  so the future's probably already  there.
She smiles and shakes her head.
(defensively) It's not like you're leaving anything  behind. A good job or something.
Just some friends.
He puts his arms around her waist from behind, and nestle her against his body.
You'll make new friends.
I know. (after a beat) I'm not eight years old. I know I'll  make new friends.
Then what is it?
She pulls away from him and starts walking to the house n door. He falls into step with her.
(uncomfortably) I, umm... I... It embarrasses me.  When you talk about something with  Carol that happened before me. She's  my best friend. It embarrasses me  that you used to live with her.
That was years ago.
Three years.
That's right.
I know...
And we're moving. She won't be your  best friend anymore.
They arrive at their front door. Beth takes out her keys. Nick stops her hand and kisses her. She kisses him back.
Living with someone isn't such a big  deal.
She nods and looks to the lock.
Anyway... I live with you now.
Beth looks to Nick. He stares out at the night.
The coffee-maker clock hits nine o'clock. The coffee make clicks on with a rattle. Steam starts to spew out. The coffee-maker makes horrible gurgling sounds.

The kitchen is small and a little grimy, its furnishings  fatigued. Nick stares at the coffee-maker in disbelief. He's dresse in a dress shirt, untied necktie, and slacks. He's carryi a sportscoat with a Sears' employee name-tag attached.
(calling out) Beth!... Beth!!
Beth walks into the kitchen, wearing a robe and carrying paper. Nick points accusingly at the coffee maker as water pours down from around its top.
It's... it's raining!
It does that.
She drops the paper on the kitchen table and gets a mug o the counter.
Since we got it?
No. (pouring herself a  cup) Lately.
(throwing his jacket  on a chair) Shit. (agitated) What's wrong with it?
Water comes out.
Shit. (unplugging the coffee  maker) I hate this shit! It never kept the  coffee hot. And now this.
He angrily wraps the cord around the coffee-maker.
(blowing on her coffee) It still works.
(adamant) No. It doesn't. Water comes out.
Okay.
She sips her coffee. She flips open a box of Dunkin' Donu
I could've gotten a new one. On my  discount. Now it's too late.
Do you want a donut?
(exasperated) No. I want an appliance that works.
Beth shrugs and takes a donut out of the box. She leans  against the counter, eating the donut. Nick walks past Beth and jams the coffee maker into the t
This coffee maker was junk.
Nick pushes a button on the blender. It makes a horrible  GRINDING WHINE. He unplugs it.
This blender's junk. Our t.v. is  junk!
He jams the blender into the trash.
I don't know why we're even bothering  to pack.
(through a mouthful  of donut) You got me.
The t.v. gets no channels.
And it's fifteen inch.
(shaking his head) I can't believe we don't have a big  t.v.
We don't watch much.
But at our age...
They stare at each other. Nick picks the almost full pint bottle of scotch off the counter and puts it in his jacke pocket. Beth takes another donut.
Why don't you take one?
I'm not hungry.
(offhandedly) Not a donut. A t.v.
Take a t.v.?
It's your last day.
Like a bonus.
Yeah.
Beth is holding a donut and her coffee mug. Nick tosses h jacket into the front seat of his old sedan.
I might do it.
I say do it. (after a beat) Sears can afford to give you a bonus.
Maybe they are.
What do you mean?
Maybe when I get my check today,  there'll be a bonus in it.
(evenly) Nick. They fired you.
Yeah...
(flatly) There's no bonus.
Yeah... That's true. (shaking his head) And I sold a lot of teevees for  them...
Beth sips her coffee, waiting for Nick to decide.
(calmly) You should take a t.v.
Nick looks at his watch.
I should go. (sarcastically) Don't wanna be late on my last day.
He kisses Beth, surprising her. He presses against her. H takes the donut from her hand and takes a bite. Beth kisses Nick, his mouth still full of donut.
Mmmmm...
He kisses her fully, then breaks the kiss.
I gotta go.
About hundred cars dot the vast parking lot. Nick swings into a parking spot and gets out of the car. tosses his jacket on the roof and crouches, tieing his ne using the car's outside mirror.
You livin' in your car or what?
CHIP, a big redheaded guy in his late thirties, wearing a jacket and tie, is grinning at the crouched Nick. Nick's  reflection grins back.
Just waiting for the last second to  put on the noose. (tightening the tie) So Chip -- what's new?
Nick straightens up and grabs his jacket. They start walk toward the mall.
Nothing much. (broaching the subject) I heard you're leaving.
Yeah. I'm outta here.
They approach the employees entrance.
They can you?
That's what they think.
Yeah?
I was gonna quit anyway -- this way  I get unemployment.
Good deal.
Nick opens the door.
Yeah... recession insurance... (Chip enters) This way I'm not stuck waiting around  for the lay-offs to start.
Nick follows Chip in.
(a hint of panic) Lay-offs?
The door shuts behind him.
The front page of the Phoenix Sun-Times -- the headline r "Misery Index Soars". Beth's hand comes INTO FRAME and crumples the page.

Beth stuffs the paper in a glass and wraps the glass in  another piece. She's sitting on the floor, surrounded by  dishes, newspaper, and cardboard liquor boxes. She adds t wrapped glass to a box. She hears the SOUND of a CAR DOOR SLAMMING, looks up, the returns to her packing. She reaches behind herself into t trash, pulls out the blender, and begins to wrap it. At the SOUND of the FRONT DOOR opening, followed by a cur METALLIC CLUNKING, she stands and hurries through the swi door to the living room.

The living room is sparsely furnished -- a sofa, a coffee table, a bookcase cluttered with a handful of paperbooks, couple of boardgames, a dying cactus, etc. A crappy old  fifteen inch t.v. on a t.v. tray. WE SEE this for a momen before... A paint-splattered cloth is unfurled FILLING THE SCREEN. It gently floats down, revealing a PAINTER and his shoppi cart overloaded with supplies. He's dressed in paint- splattered clothes. A paint-splattered Red Sox cap is pul low over his eyes, obscuring his face. Beth stares in disbelief. Without seeing her, the painter backs up, his attention focused on spreading the dropclot
Who are you?
(not looking up) The painter.
(agitated) What are you doing?
Painting.
The painter looks up from the drop-cloth, ready to deal w this obstacle. He freezes. His face lights up. It's Sid.
(extremely pleased) Well, good morning...
(recognizing him) You...
(extending a hand) Sid. Nice to see you again.
Beth stares in agitated disbelief. With his untaken extended hand, he pulls a long strip of  masking tape from a roll around his wrist, masking one si of the door frame from top to bottom.
Why are you here?
Realty office likes a fresh coat  between tenants.
(pointedly) We're still here.
He stands on his tiptoes and puts a strip of masking tape the top edge of the doorframe.
I've done this house before. (admiringly) I did a nice job.
He masks the remaining side of the door frame.
Can't you come back tomorrow?
Tomorrow's Sunday.
Yeah...?
The new people move in on Sunday. (conversationally) Where are you moving to?
(wearily) Billings, Montana.
Sid moves to a window.
(incredulous) Why?
It can't be worse than Enfield,  Arizona.
Sid pulls a strip of tape off the roll.
(smiling) I've lived in Enfield my whole life.
He holds out the end of the masking tape.
Could you hold this?
Beth takes it. He walks backwards, easing a long strip of tape off the roll.
I use this to mask. Have you ever  used masking tape to mask?
He tears the tape off the roll and sticks it to the top o the baseboard in one corner.
No. I haven't.
Crouched, he waddles across the room toward Beth, applyin the masking tape to the baseboard. He gets to Beth, stand up, takes the tape off her fingers, and presses it into p
A house like this, it's real easy.  Hardly needs a paint job.
You can skip it. I won't tell.
It needs a fresh coat...
He hands her the end of the tape again and begins another baseboard.
...a little color.
(naturally curious) What color is it gonna be?
Off-white.
He goes along the floor pressing the masking tape to the  baseboard.
It's already off-white.
No. It's white. It's just dirty.
Beth looks at the walls. He's right.
Now if it was my house, I would choose  a color...
Beth kneels down, holding the tape, as he arrives at her of the wall.
I would not choose off-white.
Beth holds out the tape. They are kneeling next to each o
What would you choose?
The color of your eyes. (pause, without looking) Hazel.
Beth stares at Sid. Sid looks to Beth. Smiling, he takes tape from her fingers.
An oasis in the center of a packed mall parking lot. Caro hurries toward the front entrance in a snappy skirt and b combo, a Bullock's name tag attached to her lapel.
Nick is sitting at a booth, a beer in front of him, lost thought. Carol arrives, drops a gift-wrapped box on the table, and scoots into the booth.
Sorry I'm late, the new girl's a  moron.
(looking to the present) What's that?
Going away present.
Nick takes it.
Thanks.
He quickly unwraps it.
(happily) A map!
I thought you might need it.
(unfolding it) I do! I had a map -- I lost it.
He spreads the map out over the table.
(organized) Let's highlight your route.
of the Western half of the U.S.A. fills the FRAME. Carol' hand, holding a bright red felt-tip pen, ENTERS FRAME.
Here's Enfield.
She circles it. Nick's finger ENTERS FRAME.
Here's Billings.
Carol circles Billings. Nick's finger starts to trace the route. Carol's pen follows, marking the route. Halfway to Billin Nick's finger abruptly stops. Carol stops the pen at the  same point.
Look at this -- right there -- that's  the town I was born in.
He looks to her for a reaction.
(emphatically) Where I grew up. Where my parent's  live... Isn't that a coincidence?
Visit them.
(shaking his head) Oh... no...
You're going to be driving by.
No... (shaking his head) They're not near the interstate. (sort of chagrined) I haven't even called them in years.
You might as well visit.
(adamantly) No. (shrugging) I wouldn't know them.
Nick starts to fold the map -- very unsuccessfully.
Shit.
Let me.
Nick hands her the map. She deftly folds it in one motion and hands it back to him.
Thanks.
He leans over the table and kisses her. She stands.
I'm starved.

Two of the walls gleam with fresh paint. Sid is painting with long-handled roller. Beth, enters, hesitates, and then -- consciously ignoring him -- walks by with a packed box and adds it to the stac by the front door.
I'm lucky I don't have to kill them.
(not a line she was  expecting) What?
If they were dark, I'd have to put a  layer of kill down first.
Beth starts back to the kitchen. Sid and THE CAMERA FOLLO
So the dark paint wouldn't shine  through the off-white.
The dishes are mostly packed.
Oh.
She picks up two empty liquor boxes.
Kill's an oil based paint.
Beth carries the boxes out of the kitchen -- Sid and THE  CAMERA FOLLOW.
Beth walks right on through followed by the talking Sid a THE CAMERA.
It covers the old paint so that you'd  never know it was there, but it gives  off fumes when it's drying.
Beth goes into the small hallway, Sid and THE CAMERA FOLL
Beth walks toward the bedroom, Sid right behind her.
Noxious fumes. They would find us on  the floor unconscious.
They enter the bedroom, THE CAMERA FOLLOWING.
There's a queen-sized bed, a bureau, a mirror, and a clos Beth takes the boxes to the closet.
They?
Sid sits on the bed, checking it's firmness.
The "they" that find people...
(interjecting) Nick.
...unconscious.
(flatly) Nick. (after a beat) The man I live with.
(smiling) I guess he'd be the "they".
He'd find us. And he'd be surprised.
Sid gets off the bed and with a grin, gingerly pats out t wrinkles he's made in the bed spread.
Nick and Carol are walking away from the Pizza Hut, acros huge parking lot, toward a large mall. Cars circle past t searching for close spots.
(doggedly) It was the drive that killed us. San  Antonio to Seattle is just too many  hours in a car. If we'd have flown,  we would've made it.
(shaking her head) No...
Things were all right in bed.
But the rest of the time they were...  awful.
(hurt) Really?
(flatly) Nick. We couldn't stand each other.  We stopped in Enfield and just stayed.
(after a beat) Why didn't you go on to Seattle? It  was your car.
Carol stops. On her face, the answer to his question is c she was stuck on Nick then and she's still stuck on him n But she'd never let him know that.
(dryly) Big trees scare me.
She starts walking. Nick hurries up beside her. They walk side by side for a few paces before the shotdown Nick com up with a new ploy to win favor.
(casually) I'm thinking about stealing a t.v.
Beth's taking extra sheets and towels from the linen clos and packing them in liquor boxes. Sid enters from the living room.
(cheerfully) I'm done in there. I won't paint the  ceiling 'til you've moved the  furniture out.
I don't think we're going to take  much of the furniture.
No?
It's ugly.
I kind of like the sofa.
It's a sofa bed.
You're not going to take it?
(flatly) It weighs two thousand pounds.
Can I have it?
It's yours.
Excellent.

The furniture is kind of ugly, but the walls look great. whole room seems brighter, almost magically more cheerful Sid runs into the room and flops onto the sofa. He settle in and sighs contentedly. The front door BURSTS open. Sid leaps up. Carol races into the room.
(excited) Nick's gonna steal a t.v.!
She sees Sid and freezes.
Who are you?
The painter.
Beth hurries into the living room.
(excitedly) He's really gonna do it?
He says yes.
Carol glances pointedly at Sid then returns her attention Beth.
(conspiratorilly) We've got to talk.
(piping in) About the crime?
(sharply) There's no crime.
Nick's gonna steal a t.v.
That's just an expression.
I've never heard that expression.
(witheringly) It's making the rounds. College  students use it.
(to Beth) Where's he stealing it from?
Sears.
(incredulous) You want him to know?
He knows. He doesn't care. (to Sid) Do you care?
(enthusiastically) I'm interested. Crime's interesting.  I read the papers.
It's not a crime.
It's justice.
Poetic justice.
How?
They fired him.
(deducing) He's got motive.
(exasperated) Who is this guy?!
The painter.
(helpfully) Sid.
He holds out a hand to shake. Carol stares at his outstre hand.
(point blank) No.

Carol takes Beth by the arm and leads her away from Sid. stares back over her shoulder at Sid. Taking the hint, he begins to stir a can of paint, assumi an air of indifference. Carol turns her attention back to Beth.
(purposefully) He needs you at the store.
(tinged w/ apprehension) He needs me?
Nick is standing next to RORY, a precocious eight year ol boy who's staring at a soap opera on a big screen t.v. As Nick and Rory talk, the soap ACTOR and ACTRESS passionate embrace.
You lookin' or buyin'?
Lookin'. I hate television.
Yeah. What do you like?
Movies.
(shaking his head) No...
I do.
(laying it out) You see... you go to a movie, you're  there.
Rory listens attentively.
You watch t.v., you're thirteen places  at once. As many channels as you  get, that's as many places as you  are. You get cable? You're forty  places at once. You get a satellite  dish?...
You're all over the world.
Exactly.
In the BACKGROUND, on the big screen t.v., the soap actre breaks the embrace and points a gun at the actor.
You're everywhere.
The soap actress shoots the actor. He stares at her in  overacting disbelief and slumps to the floor.
It's called freedom.
Carol watches as Sid whistles cheerfully, ripping the lon strips of masking tape off the trim.
(w/ attitude) This is what you do?
I also mow lawns.
Which is your career?
Painting. I'm an inside person. (confidentially) Mowing grass is seasonal.
(dryly) That is true.
Sid wads the tape into a big ball.
(disarmingly) You've got a nice tan.
(not disarmed) I work on it.
Sid shoots the tape ball into his shopping cart of suppli
Do you want to get stoned?
Carol thinks for a moment. It's been a long time and she' not crazy about him being there.
(after a beat) Yeah.
Sid takes a joint out of his shirt pocket.
This kind of painting -- for people  I won't know -- it's boring. (lighting the joint) It's not very good. It's homegrown.
He takes a drag.
Yeah?
But it'll get you fucked up.
He hands the joint to Carol.
takes a drag on the joint like an old pro.
It'll take you someplace.
Carol chokes back wheezes and then explodes in a coughing fit.

Nick and MAJOR JENKINS, a uniformed military man in his l forties, are standing in front of a wall of silent color  televisions. On the t.v.s a nearly identical pairs of LOC ANCHORS smile their way through the news.
Have you thought about American?
No.
I own an American set. I'm very  satisfied.
I want Japanese.
I'll tell you...
Nick put his arm around the man's shoulder and guides him toward a display case.
...the thing is, a hundred and fifty  dollars gets you very little in the  way of Japanese technology.
Oh.
They stop at the case. Nick points.
It would get you that t.v.
A tiny two inch Casio television playing "Gilligan's Isla
Nick looks to see the Jenkin's reaction. Jenkins stares  dumbfounded at the tiny t.v. He looks to Nick.
It's for my parents.
Your parents?
Yes. They live with me...
Beth enters the FRAME. Nick doesn't see her.
...and they want Japanese.
Nick stifles a strange urge to giggle. Beth tries to subt get Nick's attention.
Is there a problem?
(controlling the  giggles) No... I, uh, just never think of  adults as having parents.
(flatly) They do.
(agreeably) I know...
Beth fake coughs to get his attention. Nick sees her.
I'm an adult, I have parents.
Nick turns to Beth with a burst of salesman cheer.
Oh, Miss, I've got your receipt!
Beth approaches them, still not sure what Nick's up to.
(acting cheerful) Oh... great!
Nick holds out the receipt.
This is all you need.
Beth takes the receipt.
(puzzled, but playing  along) Thanks...
(personably) Now you just take this receipt out,  give it to the guys at the loading  dock and they'll give you your brand  new beautiful television set.
(thrown) I get the t.v...?
(cheerfully) Out back. They'll help load it in  your car and everything.
(flatly) I get the t.v.
Out back.
Nick turns his full attention to the man.
Think about American. They're mostly  Japanese parts anyway.
Beth stares at Nick, amazed that he's managed to come up  with a plan that has her taking the television.
Excuse me, I just...
(interrupting,  pleasantly) Miss... I'm helping this customer  here, perhaps you might... (firmly, a salesman's  put-off) You might want to see someone else.
(pointedly) You can't help me?
(after a beat, then  w/ finality) Not really.

Beth rides down on the escalator, the receipt clenched in her hand, surrounded by other shoppers, as a tinny Muzak  version of the "Theme from The Mary Tyler Moore Show" dro on in the background. Conflicting emotions cloud her face.
How'd you do it?
Nick sold a demo, wrote it up like a  new set, and gave me the receipt.
As Sid's jacknife ENTERS FRAME and zips through the packi tape, THE CAMERA PULLS BACK to reveal...

The sun is low, giving the room a golden glow. Sid and Beth are sitting on the sofa, the t.v. box on the floor in front of them. Sid opens the television box. Slowly, he pulls out the sh of bubbled packing plastic. He pops several of the bubble
(savoring the bubble  plastic) Excellent.
Maybe I should just leave it packed...
C'mon! You stole it. You gotta see  it! Hold the box.
Beth holds the box. Sid starts to lift out the television
(urgently) Wait!
Beth looks to him, anxiously.
I thought I heard the police.
Beth listens, nervously. Sid grins.
Ha ha ha. (an amused realization) You're stoned!
(innocently) Me?
You're being silly and you've got  bunny eyes.
Embarrassed, Sid pulls Visine from a pocket and drips it his eyes as he speaks.
I'm a little stoned... not that  stoned.
No?
No. (after a beat) Carol's really stoned.
You got Carol stoned?
Very stoned.
I didn't think she liked you.
She doesn't. But she likes getting  stoned.
(smiling) She does.
There's nothing like drugs to create  a quick and shallow friendship.
Beth laughs.
(rubbing his hands) Let's look at the loot.
Sid pulls the t.v. up and out of the box. He sits back on the sofa, the t.v. in his lap. The t.v. is spectacular -- huge, metallic, and ultra-mode
(very impressed) Jesus... you didn't fool around.
(w/ mixed emotions) This is the nicest thing I've ever  owned.
Beth stares at the television. Sid stares at Beth. She me his eyes, then looks quickly back to the television.
Nick is driving. His face is beaded with sweat as he drag heavily on a cigarette. He pushes the buttons on his radi getting NEWS BROADCASTS.
And in Canton, Ohio today, a man  opened fire in a mall, killing nine  and wounding seventeen others. Initial  reports indicate the young man was a  disgruntled employee...
Nick turns the radio off. He pulls the scotch bottle from his jacket and takes a sl He jerks his necktie loose and slips it over his head. He tosses it into the back seat.
swerves into a vast mall parking lot.

Through the flow of traffic, WE SEE Nick standing at a  payphone on the outside wall of a Red Lobster Restaurant. Nick speaks urgently into the phone, punctuating his  conversation with edgy body language. Abruptly, he hangs
Carol hangs up a wallphone. She leans against the  refridgerator, her expression a controlled blank. She tur her head and looks out her kitchen window.
Through Nick and Beth's living room window, WE SEE Sid  struggling under the weight of the t.v. as Beth laughingl gestures where she wants it.
Beth and Sid are kneeling on the floor in front of the t. Playing on the t.v. a rock video featuring girls, guitars and the endless highway.
It's a beautiful picture.
Sid takes the remote from Beth and turns the VOLUME UP ve loud.
(enthusiastically) Nice speakers!
Carol enters through the front door, unseen by the mesmer t. v. viewers.
(happily) Yeah! (w/ happy disbelief) Fuckin' Nick...
Sid and Beth stare at the television, completely engrosse Carol stares at them for a long moment.
(over the din, dryly) Hi, kids.

(cheerfully) Come see!
Beth turns the VOLUME DOWN as Carol comes and looks at th t.v.
(impressed) I should have had him steal me one,  too.
You can come over and watch.
Carol looks to Beth, a quizzical expression on her face.
(to Beth, quietly) You're moving.
(w/ a tinge of sadness) Oh. Right. (to Carol) Sorry.
Forget it...
Beth turns off the t.v. There's a moment of awkward silen as they all stare at the blank screen.
(breaking the silence,  pointedly) How's the painting going?
(shaking his head) Too many distractions. I'll be at it  all night.
You have bad work habits.
Not when I'm actually working. (standing) I better get set up in the kitchen.
He goes to his shopping cart of supplies. Carol and Beth  stare at the television. The television stares back at them, gleamingly modern.
It makes teevee seem very futuristic.
(at the kitchen door) That's 'cause you're stoned.
I'm hardly stoned.
She looks to Beth. Beth is grinning.
(mitigating) It was homegrown.
(teasing) Want some Visine?
(flatly) No.
(calling out) It gets the red out.
The Visine comes flying INTO FRAME. Carol fumbles, then  catches it.
(dryly) Thank you.
Carol tilts back her head and manuevers the Visine.
Shit. Missed the eye, got the face.
Need help?
Yeah.
Beth goes to her and takes the Visine.
Okay. (holding Carol's arm) Tilt your head back.
Beth...
Stop fidgeting.
She puts a drop in one eye. Carol flinches.
Got it.
Next eye.
Wait a second.
Carol blinks and wipes a Visine tear off her cheek.
(nodding to the  kitchen, in a  conspiratorial whisper) He really wants to get in your pants.
(smiling) My pants are taken.
She tilts Carol's head back.
Why don't you go for him?
He likes you.

I wish Nick would get back and help  with the packing.
She sighs, cheerfully exasperated.
He's probably getting drunk with the  stockboys... (after a beat) That's what he's probably doing.
Carol braces herself.
Beth... (pause, then w/  difficulty) Listen...
They stare into each other's eyes. After a long moment Carol averts her eyes and looks down.
(simply) He's gone.
Yeah.

I have to do something.
I'll help.
I've got to be out of here Sunday.  That's tomorrow.
You can come to my place.
(stunned) He's gone.
Beth sinks onto the arm of the sofa to support herself.
(gently) He's an asshole.
The truth makes its way deeply into her.
(a half whisper) Fuckin' Nick...
The lightly traveled highway cuts a straight line through the desert. Nick's sedan pulls off into a service station with a gian teepee beside it.

The wind is roaring, kicking up swirls of grey dust in th flourescent light of the service station. A TEENAGE NAVAJO boy is filling Nick's tank. Nick leans  against the car staring at the giant teepee.
Nobody lives in that, right?
Gift shop. But it closed at seven.
(cheerfully shrugging) I got no one to shop for.
A gust of wind sends dust into Nick's eye.
Shit. (rubbing his eye) Fuckin' wind...
Yeah.
(sincerely) What does it mean?
High pressure field coming in --  should bring some nice weather.
No. The wind itself, you know what I  mean, you're an Indian...
(correcting him) I'm a Navajo.
Yeah, so you're in tune with this  stuff...
(checking the pump) It's thirteen bucks.
(his train of thought  broken) Oh... right.
Nick pulls a bill out of his wallet and holds it out.
Here's a twenty.
The Navajo Teen takes the bill and takes a wad of bills f his pocket. Nick stares out at the moonlit desert and the mountains r in the distance.

So what does the wind mean? Like as  an omen or something, you know -- (making his voice  mystical) -- a change is coming to the people. --  the spirit of freedom is walking the  land. (flatly) That kind of meaning...
(handing him money) Fourteen, fifteen and five makes  twenty.
He opens Nick's car door for him.
The wind is. It's the wind like I'm  a Navajo.
That's it?
The Navajo teen nods.
Shit.
He gets in the car, his mood darkening, and pulls his doo shut with a slam.
(out the window) It would be better if meant something.
The Navajo teen shrugs. Nick starts the engine.

A dimly lit room filled with raucous customers and lots o neon beer signs. Waitresses in red dresses tote pitchers brew to the thirsty throng. At the far end a band plays a foot-stompin' good time tune about a trucker on his way t see his woman. THE CAMERA MOVES through the crowd and discovers Carol an Beth sitting at a small table, an almost finished pitcher beer between them. They speak loudly to be heard over the din.
He said he needs to be alone again.  Learn about himself. Make a fresh  start in a new town.
Beth shakes her head then takes a sip of her beer -- it t bitter in her mouth and she puts her glass down in disgus
(after a beat) He's sorry.
Beth stares at her beer. Carol puts a hand comfortingly o Beth's arm.
He said he would have called you,  but your phone's disconnected. 'Cause  you're moving. (after a beat) He's always been an asshole. (after a beat) You'll be all right.
Yeah...
(gently) I'm here.
I know that.
A big-haired WAITRESS approaches the table.
You ready for another?
Carol looks to Beth.
Oh... uh, no...
We're fine.
Is Nick coming in?
Carol throws the waitress a look that could kill. Beth ta a deep breath.
Nick stares at the road ahead. He takes rapid drags on a  cigarette. The RADIO is barely audible over the ROAR of t WIND through the open windows.
(covered by static) "And he arose and came to his father,  but when he was still a great way  off, his father saw him and had  compassion, and ran and..."

Nick turns the radio off. He fumbles the cigarette into the ashtray. He takes a pint of scotch from the front seat, uncaps it, takes a slug, takes another slug, recaps it, and drops it back on the seat. He stares at the road. He looks down to the front seat an finds the map. He splits his attention between the road a unfolding the map. The wind catches the map. The map billows up, covering his face. Losing control of car, Nick slaps it down. A car HORN blares. Nick jerks the car back into his lane, bats the map down  again, and pulls off to the side of the road. He stops the car and slams the shift into park. He opens his door a crack, turning on the dome light. He  smooths out the map on the dashboard. Billings and Enfield are marked with Carol's big red circ
Nick's finger traces from Enfield toward Billings along t route Carol highlighted with the red felt-tip. Halfway to Billings, the red line stops. Nick's finger stops.
He stares at the map.
Beth comes in the front door. The sound of Sid whistling  comes softly from the kitchen. Beth stares at the t.v. for a moment then strides purpose toward the kitchen.
Sid is standing on the counter masking the top sill of th kitchen window. There's half a donut hanging from his mou Beth comes through the swinging door.
(forcefully) You've lived here your whole life?
The half-donut falls from the startled Sid's mouth.
(after a beat) Yeah.
(increduously) You've never gone anywhere?
He picks up the half-donut.
Travelling has no allure for me.
None?
Sid climbs down and sits on the counter, dropping the hal donut back into the donut box.
Maybe through time.
(smiling) That's not offered.
So I stay here.
Why?
(the simple truth) It's my home. I belong here.
I'm serious.
So was Sid -- but he realizes Beth doesn't believe it can as simple as that.
My father says if you stay in one  place long enough your luck knows  where to find you.
(wryly) Maybe that's my problem.
(carefully) Maybe it is...
Sid holds out the box of donuts to her.
Thanks.
She takes a donut and fiddles with it.
You think your father knows the truth?
He's a bartender. (smiling) He's lived here his whole life.
Has his luck found him?
Not yet. (after a beat) But it's probably very close.
Beth smiles weakly. Abruptly, she drops her donut back in the box.
(cautiously) Are you all right?
(apologetically) Must be the paint fumes...
She opens up the back door and steps out. Sid stares at t empty doorway.
Beth stands in the moonlight, staring out at the stars.
(contemplatively  dubious) You find what you want here?
Sid steps out behind her.
It seems that way.
Yeah?
(simply) I found you.
Oh. No...
She walks out into the backyard. Sid follows her.
(earnestly) We never met before last night...
The moonlight through the orange trees casts a magical ai about the backyard. Beth stops by a swingset.
...but we know each other.
Beth stiffens.
No...
She walks away from him. He watches her intently.
Leave it behind.
She looks to him.
Leave what behind?
Unhappiness.
(amused) That was a bad answer.
(seriously) No. It was true.
Beth stares at Sid.
It's not.
Come hold me. (after a beat) Come hold me, and you'll be happy.
(dryly) I'll find happiness. Right. In your  arms.
Yes.
In you.
Yes.
But I won't. I have to find happiness  in myself.
No. That's wrong. (going toward her) People tell you that, but it's wrong.
She turns away from him. He stands behind her, close.
I've lived with people who have that  happiness from within. That happiness --  it's just them being pleased with  themselves. It's not enough. It's a  lonely thing.
She turns and faces him. The moonlight casts a pale glow  over them. She stares in his eyes for a long moment. She steps back  from him.
You're showing how young you are.
No. I'm not. I'm showing you a way.  You know that. And you know me. (after a beat) And I know you.
She walks away from him, back to the swingset.
I don't know you.
Sid follows and takes her arms, turning her to face him.
You know.
(after a beat,  defensively) I know you want to fuck me.
He pulls her very close. He lets go of her arms so she is standing against him, unrestrained.
Is that what you know?
Beth stares at his face for a long time.
I know...
She kisses him, suddenly, long and slow.
(whispering) I know you.
They kiss, pulling each other tight. They lose their balance and stagger against the swingset, kissing passionately. Beth pulls back.
(w/ fierce intensity) I know you.
That's right.
A canopy of stars hangs over it.

Nick is parked, staring at the house. The roadmap is on t seat beside him. He takes a drink from a half empty pint scotch. He screws the cap on and drops the bottle on the  map. He steps out of the car, unsteadily.
Nick walks toward the door. He stops, stares at the door starts back for his car. He stops, shakes his head, and w quickly to the front door.
Nick stands, staring at the door. He knocks. He waits  impatiently, then pounds on the door. On his third pound lights in the house suddenly go on.
The door abruptly opens. MR. AUGUST, an eighty year old man, stands in the doorway HE wears pajamas, slippers, and a long robe. He is over s and a half feet tall.
Nick, startled, steps back. Mr. August stares at him. Nic composes himself.
Excuse me...
Mr. August stares at him.
Excuse me... I'm... I'm looking for  my parents.
Mr. August calmly puts his hands over his ears, and slowl shakes his head.
My mother, my father... they...
ELIZABETH, a fifteen year old girl steps out from behind August. She seems very small next to Mr. August. He puts hand on her shoulder. She stares at Nick.
(uncomfortably) Hello.
Hello.
(exhaling in relief) Oh... good... (to the point) This is my house. I, uhh... mean  this is the house I grew up in.
Nick looks past them into the house.
(nodding to Mr. August) This is his house now.
Nice to meet you.
He holds out a hand to Mr. August, who slowly shakes it.
He's deaf.
(loudly) Nice to meet you.
He's stone deaf.
Oh. (uncomfortably) Yelling doesn't help.
No.
Nick breaks the handshake. Mr. August smiles at him. Nick looks to Elizabeth.
My name is Nick, Nick Brennan.
He waits for her to introduce herself. She doesn't.
Did you know the Brennans?
No.
They lived here. They used to live  here. I used to live here with them...
Elizabeth stares at him. Nick tries his salesman charm.
What's your name?
Elizabeth.
No...
Yes.
I know an Elizabeth. (quietly) I call her Beth.

Bathed in moonlight, Sid and Beth make tender passionate  love. Sid has never wanted someone so much and Beth has never f so wanted. Beth clings to Sid as if she were afraid of being swept  away... and then she is.

A chandelier casts a gently sparkling golden glow. The CAMERA TILTS down to reveal... Mr. August, Elizabeth and Nick, sitting at a large antiqu dining room table. Nick is eating a sandwich, an untouched glass of milk in  front of him. Mr. August and Elizabeth watch him, expecta Nick notices this.
(swallowing) This is a good sandwich.
Thank you.
(abruptly nodding  toward Mr. August) When did he move here? Would he know  where the people before him went?
No. He wouldn't remember.
You're sure?
Yes. He doesn't remember anymore.
Oh. (taking a deep breath) He can't help me.
No.
Nick looks around the familiar room, struck by the absurd of the situation.
(with wry awareness) I've lost my parents.
Nick smiles weakly at Elizabeth.
(matter-or-factly) Did you lose them both at the same  time?
Is that like a joke?
No.
Then yes. I lost them both at the  same time.
I lost mine one at a time. (after a beat) Last year.
Nick realizes she's talking about death.
I'm sorry. That's tragic. I should...
(interrupting) Six months apart. Body failures.  Separate body failures.
I'm really sorry. (standing) I should go.
Mr. August slowly stands as Elizabeth follows Nick toward the foyer.
First my father's heart kept starting  and stopping.
(nodding) Attacks...
Nick edges toward the door followed by Elizabeth and Mr.  August.
My mother and I were with him in the  hospital and he'd grab at us, he'd  grab my arms and hold on.
That's very sad... (after a beat, backing  toward the door) I've really gotta be going. I, uh...  thank you again for the sandwich.  Delicious...
Right before my mother died, she  said -- "Elizabeth. You're adopted."
Nick stops in his tracks, his hand on the doorknob.
Have you found your real parents?
No. Two are enough to lose.
Nick stares at her -- the sad truth of her statement sink in.
I'm not alone. I have my Grandfather.
Nick looks down. He is alone. He has no one.
(opening the door) Listen...
He looks into her eyes. Elizabeth suddenly grabs his arm. He stares at her, not knowing what to do. She holds his a tightly for a moment, then lets go.
I'm sorry.
She steps back from Nick, against her grandfather.
(in explanation) He's stone deaf.
Nick stares at Elizabeth.
I have to go.
And he hurries out the door into the night.
Beth is sitting up in bed, Sid leaning back against her, arms wrapped around him.
(after a beat) I'd like to stay right here...
I have to be out tomorrow.
In this moment... Enjoying this  moment.
They both lie perfectly still. A flicker of sadness cross Beth's face.
(hushed) The moment's gone.
(shaking his head) It can go on as long as we want.
Beth leans him back, cradling him in her arms. She stares him, a quizzical expression on her face.
(skeptically) Have you ever been in a relationship?
No. (after a beat) I was married... but it wasn't really  a relationship.
(incredulous) You weren't married...
Two years. Right out of high school.
Beth ponders this for a moment.
Do I remind you of her?
No.
(relieved) Thank God.
Sid runs his hands over her body.
You have beautiful skin... her skin  was polka-dotted.
Freckled...
When we were kids we called her  "Spot".
(laughing) What happened?
She disappeared.
Beth looks to Sid. He's staring off.
(after a beat) Was she ever found?
A flicker of loss crosses his face.
No. Not by me... (looking to Beth) I didn't go look.
Beth stares at him, uncertainly. He leans up and gently t circles on Beth's skin.
She wanted to meet someone new. I  asked her "why?" -- she said, "Because  he won't know me from before. Just  now. Just what I am now."
Beth looks to him, puzzled.

I knew her... on playgrounds... in  Sunday School... all those grades --  I knew her as she changed. But she  was still the same person. All the  times I knew her, she was still her. (after a beat) She can't get away from that.
He holds Beth tightly.

You stay in one place, and all those  things that are you... are there.  She didn't understand that if you  leave, they're still there, in you --  but they stop being clear. You stop  knowing who you are, and what you  want.
You've stayed here and you know who  you are?
He moves away from Beth.
I see the lawns I mow, houses I've  painted, faces I know... my parents...  And I'm constantly reminded of who I  am.
And you know what you want.
I want you.
Oh.
I want to be inside you.
Good. (after a beat) Come here and put it inside me.
No... I want to be able to put myself  inside of you.
Doing this is as close as you get.
Beth pulls Sid close, bringing him into her.
Come here.
I love you.
She holds him tightly.
Come inside me.
Sid arches away from her.
Beth?
Yes?
What do you want?
(uncertainly) I want... I want...
Beth pulls Sid back to her.
(w/ quiet urgency) Come inside me.
They hold each other tightly.

Nick looks like hell -- his eyes red, his hair a mess. Th nearly empty scotch bottle is on the dashboard. The car windows are open, the roar of the wind competing  with the blasting radio. Nick suddenly jerks the wheel over.
The sedan screeches off the highway into the abandoned re area. It stops facing a battered phone booth -- the engine turn off but the headlines stay shining on the phone booth.
Nick turns off the radio. It is suddenly very quiet -- on the occasional lonely DRONE OF A TRUCK passing on the hig He takes a deep breath.
Nick is standing in the phone booth, harshly lit by his  headlights.
(into the phone) Could you give me the number for  information in Arizona?... Thank  you.
Nick dials with drunken concentration.
(into the phone) Enfield. Carol, Carol, umm... (mortified) Carol... Carol Something... Shit!
He hangs up. He hits himself in the head in angry disbeli He hurriedly dials zero and listens for a moment, despera summoning up all his salesman charm.
(into the phone) Hello Janet, thank you for being my  operator. I hope you can help me, I  need to call my home.
Nick listens impatiently.

Well, I'll tell you my number, but  there's a problem. My phone's been  disconnected, not because of bills,  I mean we paid all our bills. We  were hardly ever even late. We were  very good customers, but we're moving,  so we had the phone disconnected.  But now I need to call... the woman  I live with. She's still there and  I've got to let her know where I am.
Nick listens, shaking his head emphatically.

I don't know any of the neighbors. I  know one, but I can't remember her  last name. (he listens, frustrated) No. No. No. You see you have to be  able to help me, this is not a prank,  it's my home phone, this is an  emergency. (he listens, then  urgently) Yes it can, it can be done. Someone  there can hook the phone back up.  It's not like a phone guy came to  our house to disconnect the phone,  nobody came to our house, someone  just flipped a switch somewhere,  somewhere there where you work, or  plugged something into a computer  and our phone stopped working! (he listens) They turned it off, they can turn it  back on! (he listens, starting  to panic) I know it's the week-end! I know!  Call them at home! They'll have a  computer at their house, they'll  have a phone thing to hook it up to  the real computer! That's how these  people live! They'll be glad to do  it!...
Nick listens. Suddenly all his energy drains away.

(crestfallen) No. No. I can't have the police go  to the house. That won't work, there  are circumstances. (desperately) It's you... you've got to help me!  Please! I've gotta call home! I can't  wait. It could be too late! Janet!!  You've gotta help me! Please! You  can reconnect me. Please!! Don't  hang up! Don't hang up!!
He hurls the receiver at the phone.
You fucker!! You heartless...
Nick doubles over, retching, clutching the side of the bo
"If you'd like to make a call, please  hang up and try again. If you need  help..."

Sid is sprawled out over the bed, sleeping, Beth nestled  against him. She stirs and cuddles closer. Suddenly she realizes it's not Nick. She pulls away,  orientating herself. She quickly scoots out of bed and  hurriedly pulls on a pair of jeans. The alarm clock CLANGS. Beth looks about for the alarm. She tensely scatters some boxes. She dumps one, finds the alarm and shuts it off. S stares at the clock and drops it into a box.
(cheerfully) Morning.
Beth cringes slightly and turns to face Sid.
(attempting a smile) Hi.
(grinning) Hi.
I didn't want to wake you.
(cheerfully) I'm awake. I'm a morning person.
I'm not.
Then why don't you come back to bed?
I've got to pack.
(sitting up) Where do we start?
(firmly) No. (softening) You paint.
She looks around the room littered with boxes and piles o clothes.
I'll manage.
(cheerfully) Whatever you say.
Sid gets out of bed, wrapping the sheet around himself. B stares at the room. She suddenly trembles. She steadies  herself on the bed table.
Oh God...
(concerned) What?
Beth avoids his eyes, glancing around the room.

(an outpouring) I'd be so much happier if I could  blame this on Nick, but it always  happens to me. I'm always left with  nothing. (taking a deep breath) It doesn't matter if I leave the guy  or if the guy leaves me -- I'm left  with nothing. I never do anything  for myself. I never acquire anything.  I mean Nick didn't take from me. He  stole a t.v. and left it for me. He  didn't take my things, he didn't  take our things... he didn't even  take his clothes! And I'll still  leave this house with nothing!
He took three years from you.
No... (meeting his eyes) He didn't take 'em. I mean, when he  cared about me, he cared about me.  And he was really good in bed.
She glances away from Sid toward the bed.
(after a beat) I didn't expect more.
She turns away from Sid and the bed. Sid moves toward her
(carefully) Beth...
Beth summons up all the composure she can manage.
(referring to the  cluttered room) I can't face this. (looking to Sid) I'm gonna finish up the kitchen... (heading for the door) ...get some momentum...
She goes out the bedroom door. Sid stares after her.

Nick's sedan is parked in the same place as the night bef A YOUNG MAN with long hair ROARS into the rest stop on a  Harley-Davidson, his life's possession strapped on the ba He stops the bike between Nick's car and the phonebooth,  idling the engine, loudly. He looks to the phonebooth, th receiver dangling. He turns to Nick's sedan.
Phone work?
Awakened by the ROAR, Nick has wearily leaned his head ou the window. Nick stares at the young man.
(after a beat) No.

Drained, Nick rests his head on the steering wheel. OFFSCREEN, the motorcycle starts up and zooms away. A sil falls over the rest stop. Without raising his head from the steering wheel, Nick st the car.
Sid is making the bed.
(gleefully  conspiratorially) How was he?
(sheepishly) He's twenty-four.
Sid pulls up the blanket and fluffs the pillows.
A little weak on tenderness, but  long on juice?
Long on conversation.
The cupboards are all open and bare. A half dozen boxes a neatly stacked. Beth is sitting on the floor packing the  final dishes. Carol holds out a mug of coffee.
Did you need talk?
Beth stands and takes the coffee.
Yeah. I guess I did.
Good.
Beth sips her coffee, gazing out the kitchen window.
The backyard. In the light of day it's lost its magical  quality. The grass needs cutting and is marred by brown  patches. The swingset looks pathetically rusted and  dilapidated.
Her face clouds over.
(cheerfully) So what are we doing?
Carol is staring at Beth staring out at the backyard.
Christ...
She turns to Carol.
(w/ an edge of  desperation) I gotta get out here. I was in Tucson  two years before you and Nick got  here. (in disbelief) I've been here five years...
Yeah...
This state's driving me crazy.
So what are you gonna do?
I've got no money.
I've got some.

(chagrined by self- awareness) I can't take it. I mean you're being  great, but I can't take it. I'm gonna  be gone, we won't see each other,  and I won't send the money. I won't.  I know... I won't get around, I'll  forget, I won't do it.
She looks around the room in disgust.
(agitated) Shit. I'll sell all this shit. I  don't want any of it, just my car  and my clothes...
(carefully) Okay...
(shaking her head) I'm sorry... I shouldn't have fucked  this kid last night. I should have  slept. Now I've got all this stuff  to do, and I'm tired, I'm churned  up, I'm in a fuckin' mood.
Let's do things, get you busy.
Yeah.
You get all the stuff you wanna sell,  and I'll make some tag sale signs.
No one'll buy my stuff. It's all  junk.
That's what people buy at tag sales.  Broken appliances, ugly knicknacks.
Beth looks at the semi-packed boxes.
(laughing) I guess I do have stuff to sell.

Boxes full of a motley collection of knickknacks, housewa and crummy appliances are spread out on the lawn. In the BACKGROUND a couple of M.T.V. influenced teens are checking out the knickknacks and goofing on them. MRS. DOTSON, a woman in her late forties wearing a NURSE' UNIFORM is poking through the odds and ends. Beth and Carol hovering near her. Mrs. Dotson picks up the coffee maker, examines it, and p it down. She picks up the blender, examines it, and puts down.
(impatiently) Is there something specific you're  looking for?
Yes. (sheepishly) Actually everything... I don't have  anything.
Nothing?
